results.title: My Omeo: A Short History
results.creator_credit: David Withers, Csilla Csongvay and ACMI
results.brief_description: Jeff Cooper is a guardian of all things great about Omeo and its chequered history. His role within the community is not only as a custodian of the local records but also as a passionate tour guide of the Omeo Historic Park and local gold fields. The Park contains 5 heritage-listed buildings that are believed to be some of the most intact and original in Australia. Jeff believes Omeo is the last bastion of self-funded retirement and despite losing his home and livestock in the 2003 bushfires, wouldn’t live anywhere else in the world.

results.title: Deirdre Jack: Swifts Creek Artist
results.creator_credit: Matt Blackwood, Csilla Csongvay, David Withers and ACMI
results.brief_description: Local painter, Deirdre Jack, is passionate about her local environment. The rolling hills and golden fields that surround her Swifts Creek bush studio inevitably make their way into her vibrant oil paintings and pastel sketches. Fruit, however, is the main subject of her exhibition at the Great Alpine Gallery, a small exhibition space that sits in the heart of Swifts Creek and run voluntarily by a group of fellow artists. The gallery has been a vital place for local artists since 1989 despite the challenges of running an art space in a small rural town.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Matt Blackwood, Csilla Csongvay, David Withers and ACMI

results.title: The Swifts Creek Bush Nursing Centre
results.creator_credit: Matt Blackwood, Csilla Csongvay, David Withers and ACMI
results.brief_description: The small country town of Swifts Creek has had a bush nursing service since 1918 when staff were originally travelling on horseback. These days the bush nurse Sue Carroll visits patients in a 4WD and understands the importance of providing medical care to locals that are often isolated and unable to travel to the Omeo Hospital. Whether it’s farmers in need of wound management, children with the measles or victims of car accidents, Carroll is usually the first person on the scene. Part nurse, part social worker, all legend; Carroll and the staff at the Swifts Creek Bush Nursing Centre provide a vital 24/7 service to not only the local community but the wider surrounding regional area.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Matt Blackwood, Csilla Csongvay, David Withers and ACMI

results.title: Warwick Thornton: Mother Courage interview
results.creator_credit: Jim Arneman, Csilla Csongvay, Kim Montgomery and ACMI
results.brief_description:
In this interview, Warwick talks about his early days in Alice Springs and getting his start in radio before moving on to films. Warwick also discusses the reoccurring theme of the matriarch in his works and the freedom and joy he finds in installation art.

‘Mother Courage’ is a film and sculptural installation by the internationally acclaimed artist and filmmaker Warwick Thornton. Co-commissioned by ACMI and dOCUMENTA (13) as part of the ACMI Commissions Series, ‘Warwick Thornton: Mother Courage’ was a free exhibition in Gallery Two at ACMI 2013. As one of the most exciting filmmakers working in Australia today, Warwick Thornton is best known for ‘Samson & Delilah’, winner of the 2009 Camera d’Or at the Cannes Film Festival. His work, ‘Mother Courage’ (2012), is a dynamic, multi-screen art installation that features a dilapidated campervan as its centrepiece. Audiences will peer into the van’s grimy windows and through its rear doors, to view the provocative and poignant video contained within.

results.title: Folk, Rhythm and Life
results.creator_credit: Roberto Salvatore, Shelley Matulick, ACMI Content Development and ACMI
results.brief_description: The Skermer Famliy have been running the Bilyana ‘Folk Rhythm & Life Festival’, in north-eastern Victoria, since 1996 and in the process raising funds for local and international charities. The festival has always been environmentally sustainable, with the original “drop dunnies” developed by Hamish Skermer now being used not only in Eldorado but also at festivals in Australia and overseas.

results.title: The Eldorado Museum
results.creator_credit: Roberto Salvatore, Shelley Matulick, ACMI Content Development and ACMI
results.brief_description: Sue Phillips, Sandra Buchan and Geoff Milne take us on a tour of the Eldorado Museum and share the rich history of the pioneering families who established infrastructure and made the northern Victorian town of Eldorado what it is in 2012.

results.title: Artists of Eldorado
results.creator_credit: Roberto Salvatore, Shelley Matulick, ACMI Content Development and ACMI
results.brief_description: Meet local artists Maureen Hearn, Denise Ellison, Thea Day, Sandra Buchan and Sam Anderson, and learn about their inspirations and artistic practice. Moved by the magic of Eldorado, in northern Victoria, these artists are never short of inspiration. Day, Ellison and Buchan make time each week to get together and share their passion for painting and line drawing. Hearn works out of her studio that showcases her love of the river and obsession with chickens. Anderson is a metal sculptor who works on his family farm creating large scale works, such as his ‘Gorilla’, which must be seen to be believed.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Roberto Salvatore, Shelley Matulick, ACMI Content Development and ACMI

results.title: The Greta Swamp
results.creator_credit: David Withers, Csilla Csongvay, Shelley Matulick, ACMI Content Development and ACMI
results.brief_description: The area surrounding Greta, in north-eastern Victoria, used to be a swamp, home to indigenous wildlife and the mythical Bunyip creature. The swamp was drained as part of a government employment project in the 1890s, leaving behind rich fertile land ideal for grazing, however it also created a complete change in the area around Greta, especially in the hill country, causing environmental damage. One hundred years on and local Land Care members Anthony and David Griffiths, along with 2012 Land Care President Phil Gottschling, have dedicated their time and energy to try and reverse the effects of the dredging and are revegetating their land to restore balance to the environment.

results.title: Greta Craft Group
results.creator_credit: Matt Blackwood, Csilla Csongvay, Shelley Matulick, ACMI Content Development and ACMI
results.brief_description: Women come from great distances bringing their knitting needles, sewing machines and a good yarn to the weekly Greta Craft Group. The group was started by Kath White in the early 1990s when, as a young mum and new to the area, she reached out to other mums for some companionship. The group grew from there and became so popular they needed a waiting list for those interested to join - as Winifred Suffield suggests “craft is just an excuse to meet”. 2012 President Helen Bird and long time members Nola Jones and Julie White, speak about the support and friendship that the group has provided over decades. We hear the sounds of laughter and chatter as the ladies make all sorts of beautiful crafts which they provide to charities, both locally and internationally.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Matt Blackwood, Csilla Csongvay, Shelley Matulick, ACMI Content Development and ACMI

results.title: The Greta Bunyip Newsletter
results.creator_credit: David Withers, Csilla Csongvay, Shelley Matulick, ACMI Content Development and ACMI
results.brief_description: In the digital age it’s all well and good for those who are connected via high speed internet, but in some rural towns it is the good old fashioned newsletter that keeps locals in the know. The Bunyip Newsletter is hand-delivered across the wider Greta area by six committed volunteers. We meet Noeleen Lloyd and Allan Porker as well as local historian Joan Ellis and hear about the importance of having a local newsletter. ‘The Bunyip’ was born out of a demand from the locals to be better informed and more connected to their community and surrounds. Over 300 newsletters are distributed every two months containing articles of historical, sporting and community importance.
